16.0: Ad-noy Elokim commanded. Hashem would not have commanded Adam to begin with if he possessed no intelligence. Moreover, he obviously possessed the intellect to give names to the other creatures. It was only knowledge of good and evil that he lacked.

0.0: And it said to the woman. Some say that Chavah understood the gesticulations of the animals. According to Rav Sadyah Gaon, however, whenever speech is ascribed to an animal it is actually an angel that is speaking on its behalf. Alternatively, it is possible that these verses are to be taken literally, since it is no more difficult for Hashem to give intelligence to a serpent than to human beings.

28.0: This one will bring us rest (or “consolation”). Adam informed Lemech through prophecy that his son would bring about the salvation of the world.

8.2: In his generation (literally, “generations”). In the generation of the Flood and all the succeeding generations through which he lived. Noach did not die until Avraham was fifty-eight years old.

10.0: Before Elokim. That is, in public. Alternatively, it means that performed their corrupt deeds in private so that only Hashem knew of them.

4.0: Noach did all. At this point he only brought his family near to the ark but did not enter.

6.0: Because of the waters. Out of fear of the impending flood. Two by two they came. During the seven days the animals came to the ark of their own accord.

10.2: Behold I now realize. In Canaan there were other women as beautiful as Sarah but not in Egypt, because physical appearance is affected by climate

0.1: I am your shield. I was the one who protected you from the four kings and I will also reward you for trusting in Me and going to the rescue of your nephew.

25.0: Within the city. That is, they display their fear of Heaven openly.

2.0: Elokim came. An angel appeared to him on Avraham’s behalf. Pharaoh was afflicted with severe plagues (12:17) whereas regarding Avimelech it is written only that Hashem “restrained every womb.” This is because Avimelech was less wicked than Pharaoh.

3.0: Will You also kill an innocent nation. He prayed on behalf of his entire nation.

13.0: Bread and a skin of water. Since Hashem told him to listen to all that Sarah said he could not give Hagar anything without Sarah’s permission. Nevertheless, after Sarah’s death he gave the sons of his concubines gifts (25:6).
13.1: It is also possible that he gave Hagar gifts that Scripture does not mention. She went and lost her way. Avraham gave her sufficient supplies to reach Beer Sheva had she not become lost.

1.0: Under my thigh. This was the custom of the time. It was a way of indicating that the underling was under the master’s authority and his hand was his to do with as he wished.

48.0: Kind. It is a kindness, because you are not obliged to agree.
48.1: And true. Or, “in good faith” — that is, if you will then carry out the promised kindness in deed.

54.0: Her brother and mother said. Since they were the ones who received the gifts, they were the ones who spoke up. Alternatively, Lavan spoke in his father’s stead because he was the cleverer of the two.

0.0: Keturah. This cannot be Hagar because in verse 6, Scripture refers to Avraham’s concubines in the plural.

21.0: Why did I desire this (or, “why am I [so different]”). She asked experienced mothers whether what she was going through was normal and was told that it was not.

31.0: I am about to die. Eisov observed that on account of his hazardous life as a hunter he might very well die before his father and never enjoy the portion of the first born.

33.0: Eisov scorned the birthright. He saw that his father had become poor in his old age and that there was little for him to inherit.

34.0: This time I will praise. After having borne four sons. Because Leah was content with this number, she stopped giving birth.

32.0: The tents (literally, “the tent”) of the two handmaids. The two of them shared one tent. Alternatively, he entered the tent of one of the two handmaids. He left Leah’s tent. After he left the tents of the handmaids he returned to Leah’s tent. Alternatively, Scripture delayed mentioning that he entered Rochel’s tent immediately upon leaving Leah’s in order to conclude with Rochel’s subterfuge.

18.0: The part of the field. One who acquires a portion in the Holy Land is likened to one who acquires a portion in the World to Come.

13.1: He poured a libation on it. He washed it either with water or with wine before offering oil upon it. At the same time he also fulfilled his vow to separate a tenth for Hashem (28:22), which he then gave to whoever was most worthy of receiving it in those days.

1.0: And the lad. Because of his youth the sons of the maidservants made him their lackey. This was the “bad report” that he brought to their father.

22.0: They stripped him of his coat. A kutones is actually an undergarment. Thus they cast him into the pit completely naked.

22.1: Lest we are humiliated. Lest I become a subject of ridicule for yielding up my ring, my wrap and my staff for such an ignoble purpose.

5.0: Except for the bread he ate. He would not allow Yoseif to touch his bread because he was a Hebrew; see 43:32.

47.0: All the food. That is, all that was possible to gather without causing the people to starve.

6.2: He recognized … Yoseif recognized. He knew immediately that they were his brothers, but only after he examined them more carefully did he know who was who.

27.0: They bowed (vayikdu) … and prostrated. They lowered their heads (kadkod) to the ground after having already prostrated themselves.

19.0: A father who is old. Since the oldest brother was only 45 it was not self-evident that their father was very old.

22.0: The sons of Don [were] Chushim. Note the plural — “sons.” He may have had another son who died.

33.0: Since every shepherd is abhorrent. The Egyptians of those times were vegetarians like modern Hindus.

6.0: Cursed be their anger. He prophesied — or prayed — that their fiery tempers would cool down.
6.2: I will disperse them. Both Shimon and Leivi received scattered cities rather than a contiguous portion.
